data.title: Unhandled mouse events while captured cause endless objects to be created
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux, LXQt (OpenBox)
Godot master 0bf88e4 amd_64 release_debug

**Issue description:**
While the mouse is captured (only `Input.set_mouse_mode(Input.MOUSE_MODE_CAPTURED)`), Performance monitors `OBJECT_COUNT` and `MEMORY_STATIC` increase (forever?) with any mouse input event that isn't handled with `set_input_as_handled()`.

The object count / memory returns to normal as soon as the mouse mode is changed.

Now I should actually be consuming the events in most cases, but the behaviour when you don't seems undesirable regardless.


**Steps to reproduce:**
I wrote a quick script to test this. Scene is just a Node with a Label child.
```
extends Node

func _input(event):
	if event is InputEventMouseMotion:
		#get_tree().set_input_as_handled()
		pass
	elif event is InputEventMouseButton:
		#get_tree().set_input_as_handled()
		pass
	elif event is InputEventKey:
		if event.scancode == KEY_ESCAPE:
			Input.set_mouse_mode(0)
		elif event.scancode == KEY_SPACE:
			Input.set_mouse_mode(Input.MOUSE_MODE_CAPTURED)
	
	$Label.set_text("objects: %d\nstatic mem: %d" % [Performance.get_monitor(Performance.OBJECT_COUNT), Performance.get_monitor(Performance.MEMORY_STATIC)])
```

data.title: [3.0 Spatial] Ghost-Effect Material: Simply using Rim and Refraction to get an eerie invisible-glow effect. Also, suggestions for enhancing the Rim options.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Godot 3.0 Pre-Alpha Build, Windows 10

Lately I've been messing around with the Spatial material to try to create a invisible/phantom/glowing membrane like material and was able to make this:

![godot_ghost_effect](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5027750/27992575-b6509826-644c-11e7-8675-acbf477bc8c9.png)

Utilizing Rim to get the glowing edges and Refraction for the invisible distortion, this was the most impressive (or probably a not-bad, first time attempt) in recreating the effect. For Rim it turns out that despite the "Tint" adjustment goes up to 1 in maximum, there is no limit to how low the minimum is required. For example: adjust Tint to -100 and you have a blended glowing edge on your object!

Refraction is simple enough to utilize to get the invisble effect.

The idea and main point in this is that the Rim has the potential to be enhanced further so then it can be utilized in maybe creative ways. For example, ghosts or creepy, invisible membrane like object (Sorta like how Metroids have a near invisisble but glowing membrane)

What extras Rim should/could have:

- Make the Rim colorable, so then it does not use the same white glow,
- An adjustment bar or boolean for the rim glow to be "emittable", (Turns out you need a light source or directional light to get the glow, would be awesome if the rim was made emittable without a light source. Better if using an adjustment bar for animation or programming purposes.)
- Make an adjustment bar to adjust the width or visibility of the glowing rim so then typing -100 into the "tint" isn't used.
- And allow a boolean option whether different objects with rims appear behind the other invisble/rim objects (As you can see in the example image, the rims does not overlap or merge completely within another object.)

**Steps to reproduce:**

Add a new mesh to the scene, make a new material:

-Add a directional light to get the Rim glow.
-Adjust the Albedo's Alpha adjustment bar so then refraction can work,
-Set the Metallic to 0 and the Metallic Specular to 0 to avoid glassy reflections in refraction,
-Set Roughness to 0
-Enable Rim, set rim to "1", and type in the tint adjustment: "-100", trust me it works despite breaking limitations. (P.S. Unless there is an option to adjust the with of the rim, don't patch it.)
-Enable Refraction, set scale to 0.07. This allows distortion in invisibility
-(OPTIONAL): You can try to use Normalmapping to add details.

I can already imagine a lot of ghosts/spirits/souls flying around in a game project involving jumpscares, ghost hunting, or etc.

data.title: Need to be able to upate a texture partially
data.body: I'm writing a HeightMap module , and when the heights are edited it would be nice to be able to update only a sub-rectangle of the textures instead of the full 2048x2048 pixels. My editing process is chunked already for efficiency, but uploading the textures would be faster with this feature.

data.title: Creating a Shader Material in a Spatial Material's NextPass Crashes the Editor
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Manjaro 64bit godot 3.0

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When I make a new Spatial Material then go to NextPass and try to make a Shader Material the editor crashes. 
**NOTE:**

 This only happens with a Shader Material being made In the NextPass of a Spatial Material. Making a Shader Material in the NextPass of any other Material type still works fine.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1) Make a Spatial Material
2) Find Next Pass
3) Make a new Shader Material

Also I am using the latest material tester demo

I suggest renaming the following:

ColorRect.set_frame_color -> ColorRect.set_color
ColorRect.get_frame_color -> ColorRect.get_color

same with

ColorPickerButton.set_pick_color -> ColorPickerButton.set_color
ColorPickerButton.get_pick_color -> ColorPickerButton.get_color

data.title: Glow in Softlight and Screen mode create artifacts.
data.body:
**Godot version: 3.0 master**

**Issue description:**
If you set Glow blending to Softlight or Screen skybox texture starts looking weird. Occasionally in some places reflections also look weird.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Add Environment Node with sky texture (or use Material Tester demo)
2. Turn on Glow
3. Change Glow blending to softlight or screen.

data.title: option to dynamically adjust fixed_fps based upon a user's monitor's refresh rate (hz)
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1.4, any

**Issue description:**
I just found this nasty issue out after buying a 144hz monitor.

I previewed my game scene and there was a huge jitter when moving. I originally thought it had to do https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/2043#issue-85903385

The fix is changing your "fixed_fps" variable under _physics_ to 144. Once you do that, there is ZERO jitter ANYWHERE. It's all gone

**The problem is. In godot, there is no way to dynamically **and programmatically** set this before loading the game.**

- For example, if I ship my game out at a fixed_fps variable of 144. Only players who have a 144hz monitor will get NO JITTER. Anyone with a 60hz monitor wll experience massive jitter.

- For example #2: If I ship my game out at a fixed_fps at 60 or "default" (0), people with a 144hz monitor will experience massive jitter.

I'm suggesting maybe a method that is available in the `OS` class that grabs the refresh rate of the monitor? Maybe that would help? And then godot developers can just call that before loading an extensive physics game world scene, etc.

data.title: [3.0] During Import Process of Assets Engine Crashes
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10
Godot 3.0

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When the engine starts it tries to auto import resources. During this process I receive the following errors:

This error occurs throughout the import process:
ERROR: _gl_debug_print: GL ERROR: Source: OpenGL        Type: Error     ID: 1282        Severity: High  Message: Error has been generated. GL error GL_INVALID_OPERATION in DisableVertexAttribArray: (ID: 3860911800) Generic error

+And this last error is what i get before it crashes: 
ERROR: alloc_static: Condition ' !mem ' is true. returned: __null
   At: core/os/memory.cpp:67


**Steps to reproduce:**
Have about 11MB worth of pngs in the res:// location to import.

Start the engine and let the auto import process at the beginning run

data.title: ScriptCreateDialog: Fix regressions from #9536
data.body:
#9536 creates Native script with template which is not supported. Also crashes the editor in some cases due to index out of range.
Also I've concluded that the dialog should retain current behavior regarding remembering languages without template (remember Native and the "Default template"). This shouldn't affect usability of majority of users, but if it is, a proper usability fix could be made.

data.title: Compile failure VS2015: cannot convert argument 1 from 'Image' to 'const Ref &'
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 - Godot 3.0


**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
Compile failure as follows:
scons: *** [editor\editor_initialize_ssl.windows.tools.32.obj] Error 2
editor\editor_icons.cpp(5943): error C2664: 'void ImageTexture::create_from_image(const Ref<Image> &,uint32_t)': cannot convert argument 1 from 'Image' to 'const Ref<Image> &'
editor\editor_icons.cpp(5943): note: Reason: cannot convert from 'Image' to 'const Ref<Image>'
editor\editor_icons.cpp(5943): note: No user-defined-conversion operator available that can perform this conversion, or the operator cannot be called
scons: *** [editor\editor_icons.windows.tools.32.obj] Error 2
scons: building terminated because of errors.


**Steps to reproduce:**
pull down current master branch
compile code using scons platform=windows in the Developer Command Prompt for VS2015 at the root directory of the godot project

data.title: [3.0] String.match() not found.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 17.10 - Godot v3.0-alpha.custom_build

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
I compiled the master branch yesterday evening and I am not able to use the String.match() function anymore.

Whatever parameter I pass, it raises the following error:
> error(9, 13): Expected identifier as member

The String.matchn() function seems work though.

It's weird because the ustring.cpp code has not been touched for a long time :confused: 

**Steps to reproduce:**

```gdscript
extends Node

func _ready():
	var title = 'Hello world!'
	print(title.match('Hello*'))
```

data.title: [3.0] Add options for more human-friendly build output
data.body: Same as #9551, but for the current `master` branch.

data.title: shadow/matte material - no render, only shadow, reflection etc.
data.body:
So this trick has been around for many years in software such as blender and 3ds max. They have a material that receives shadows, or reflections and effects. As the user chooses.

It would be really handy to have a material like this! Im working on something where I need an invisible ground plane. But I want reflections and shadows on the invisible ground.....

Is there anything like this in gd3?

data.title: [2.1] Add options for more human-friendly build output
data.body:
This PR adds a little progress indicator to SCons's command line output when building.

The progress indicator is **enabled by default** and can be turned off with `progress=no`.
The options `verbose` and `warnings` now default to `no`.
There is a new quick switch, `dev=yes`, which is an alias for `verbose=yes warnings=all`.

Build output with `progress=yes`:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8849554/27984239-db68e7c0-63d0-11e7-82e3-402c5d6b2a33.png)

data.title: more flexibile camera placment methods
data.body:
I havent found a way to freecam an in editor camera. This is by far the best way to position and animate cameras by actually looking through them in the fps view. Then locking them in place once your happy with the shot.

Also would be great to have some kind of safe frame preview for framing shots.

Maybe a way to snap a camera to the current view also would be a handy addition with that.

data.title: Editor is not rendered correctly on macOS with two displays
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
macOS Sierra 10.12.5, MacBook Pro Retina 2015 connected to 27-inch Thunderbolt Display.
Godot v2.1.3.stable.official

**Issue description:**
The editor looks like this when you open any project:
![Godot Editor](https://i.imgur.com/PuuPK0x.png)
It looks like the editor is not able to determine upper and right bounds of the window or something. Resizing the window still keeps things the same.
Input handling for the controls I see works fine, but obviously this issue makes the editor unusable.

If I disconnect the MacBook from the Thunderbolt Display and reopen the project, the editor looks/works fine.

As an additional note, the project selection dialog works fine with two displays.
